#Text=Mansour announces election plans for Egypt after violence and protests
#Text=Tuesday , July 9 , 2013
#Text=Egyptians in Tahrir Square celebrating the removal of President Morsi on Sunday .
#Text=Last night , Adly Mansour , the interim leader of Egypt , announced plans to reform Egypt 's constitution and hold a new round of parliamentary and presidential elections .
#Text=The interim president also announced a judicial investigation into yesterday 's shooting of at least 51 supporters of deposed president Mohamed Morsi .
#Text=Mansour plans to form a panel within fifteen days to review and suggest changes to the now-suspended constitution .
#Text=Those amendments would be voted on in a referendum within four months .
#Text=Parliamentary elections would then be held , perhaps in early 2014 , followed by presidential elections upon the forming of a new parliament .

#Text=Yesterday in Cairo , protestors supporting Mohamed Morsi and the Muslim Brotherhood were shot outside the Presidential Guard barracks , where pro-Morsi supporters believe the former president is being kept under arrest .
#Text=The Muslim Brotherhood claim 53 people died , while the health ministry claim 51 people died and 435 were injured .
#Text=The Muslim Brotherhood claim the attack was unprovoked and those gathered were praying .
#Text=Colonel Ahmed Mohammed Ali , spokesman for the army , said the group had attacked security forces and were armed with " large quantities of firearms , ammunition and Molotov cocktails " .

column1: #Text=The Muslim Brotherhood claimed children were killed in the conflict but Colonel Ali claims the photos being used by the Muslim Brotherhood are actually photos from Syria in March .
#Text=Colonel Ali also stated two policemen and a soldier were killed .
#Text=One of the survivors , Mohamed Saber el-Sebaei , told journalists he was praying when the confrontation started :
#Text=" Just before we finished , the shooting started .

#Text=All sides of the political spectrum should work together for the sake of the country 's political and economic future .

#Text=Former British Prime Minister Tony Blair said the intervention by the army was necessary to prevent  chaos " , and said the protests that led to the downfall of Morsi are due to dissatisfaction with the efficacy of government :

column1: #Text=" When governments do n't deliver , people protest .

column3:

column1: #Text=" People felt that the Brotherhood was steadily imposing its own doctrines on everyday life " .

#Text=Blair advised Western governments to " engage with the new de facto power and help the new government make the changes necessary , especially on the economy , so they can deliver for the people .
